message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the baby’s tongue suggest oral thrush, which is a fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals. The fact that the baby received no prenatal care makes it more likely that the mother had HIV, and thus zidovudine (an antiretroviral drug) given during pregnancy and delivery could have prevented the baby's condition. Fluconazole is an antifungal drug used to treat thrush, but it would not prevent the condition. Penicillin G and rifampin are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing thrush.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The poor weight gain and chronic diarrhea suggest that the patient has HIV/AIDS. The thick white plaques on the tongue are indicative of oral thrush, which is a common opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients. Zidovudine (AZT) is an antiretroviral drug used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV during pregnancy and childbirth, and it can help reduce the incidence and severity of opportunistic infections such as oral thrush.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the surface of the tongue that can be easily scraped off are indicative of oral thrush, which is caused by the fungal organism Candida albicans. This condition is common in people with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV infection. Administration of Zidovudine, an antiretroviral medication used to treat HIV, would have prevented this patient's condition. None of the other options are effective against fungal infections or HIV. Penicillin G is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections. Rifampin is used to treat bacterial infections such as tuberculosis. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication but is not indicated for prevention of oral thrush in patients with HIV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest thrush, which is caused by Candida albicans. This infection is common in infants who have received no prenatal care or have weakened immune systems. Zidovudine is an antiretroviral medication used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV, which can weaken the immune system and increase the risk of thrush. Therefore, Zidovudine administration during pregnancy and delivery is likely to have prevented this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the surface of the tongue suggest thrush, which is caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans. This is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients and can be prevented with zidovudine, an antiretroviral medication used to prevent HIV infection from being passed from mother to child during birth.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the surface of the patient’s tongue suggest oral thrush, which is commonly seen in infants with HIV infection. Zidovudine is an antiretroviral therapy that can prevent mother-to-child HIV transmission, thus preventing this patient’s condition. The other options are not relevant to the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of poor weight gain, chronic diarrhea, and thrush suggest a possible HIV infection. Zidovudine is an antiretroviral drug that can prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV during pregnancy and delivery. The other options are not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of thick white plaques on the surface of the tongue that can be easily scraped off is characteristic of thrush, which is caused by a fungal infection (Candida albicans). This can occur due to a weakened immune system, which can be caused by HIV infection. Zidovudine is used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV during pregnancy and delivery, and could have prevented the patient's condition if his mother had received prenatal care and been treated. None of the other options (fluconazole, penicillin G, or rifampin) are used to prevent or treat thrush or HIV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the surface of the tongue are consistent with thrush, which is caused by the fungus Candida. This patient most likely has an underlying immunodeficiency, possibly due to HIV infection. Zidovudine is an antiretroviral medication used to treat HIV and has been shown to reduce the risk of opportunistic infections like thrush. Therefore, the administration of Zidovudine could have prevented this patient's condition. None of the other options would have been effective in preventing or treating thrush in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thick white plaques on the tongue that can easily be scraped off suggest oral thrush, which is a common sign of HIV in infants. Zidovudine is an antiviral medication that can prevent transmission of HIV from mother to baby during pregnancy, labor, and delivery. Therefore, if the mother had received prenatal care and been treated with Zidovudine during pregnancy, the baby would have been less likely to contract HIV and develop oral thrush. None of the other options would have prevented this patient's condition.
